written.q: 1. What is the difference between casual listening and focused listening? What are the stages you would follow in teaching listening?
written.a:
Casual vs. Focused Listening

Casual Listening is when we listen for pleasure or to get a general idea of something, without trying to catch every detail. Examples include listening to music while working or half-listening to a conversation in the background. The goal is enjoyment or general awareness.

Focused Listening (or active listening) is when we listen carefully to understand specific information. We pay close attention to details, facts, and the speaker's main points. Examples include listening to a teacher's lecture or following instructions to complete a task. The goal is comprehension and information gathering.

Stages of Teaching Listening

A typical listening lesson is structured in three stages:

  1. Pre-listening: This stage prepares the students for what they are about to hear. Activities include introducing the topic, teaching key vocabulary, and asking students to predict what the listening text will be about. This activates their prior knowledge.
  2. While-listening: In this stage, students listen to the audio for a specific purpose. The first time, they might listen for the main idea (gist). The second time, they might listen for specific details or answers to questions.
  3. Post-listening: This stage involves follow-up activities. Students might discuss their answers, summarize the text, have a debate on the topic, or do a role-play related to the listening content. This helps to consolidate their understanding.

written.q: Or, What is Psycholinguistics? Write in brief about the main stages of language development.
written.a:
Psycholinguistics

Psycholinguistics is the study of the mental aspects of language. It explores how the human mind understands, produces, and acquires language. It combines psychology and linguistics to investigate the brain processes that allow us to use language, from recognizing sounds and words to forming complex sentences.

Main Stages of Language Development

Children typically acquire language in the following stages:

  1. The Pre-linguistic Stage (0-12 months): Babies communicate through crying, cooing, and then babbling (e.g., 'ma-ma-ma'). They are learning the sounds of their native language.
  2. The Holophrastic (One-Word) Stage (12-18 months): Children use single words to express full ideas. 'Ball' could mean 'I want the ball' or 'Look at the ball'.
  3. The Two-Word Stage (18-24 months): Children combine two words to make simple sentences like 'Daddy car' or 'Want cookie'.
  4. The Telegraphic Stage (2-3 years): Sentences become longer but often lack grammatical words, like a telegram. A child might say, 'Cat drink milk' instead of 'The cat is drinking milk'.
  5. Later Development (3+ years): Language skills grow rapidly. Children begin to use more complex grammar, ask questions, and tell stories.

written.q: 2. Write your personal opinions with arguments in favour of the statement "Jonathan Swift was an Misanthropist."
written.a:
Opinion: Jonathan Swift as a Misanthrope

It is a strong argument that Jonathan Swift was a misanthrope, or a hater of humanity. This view is most powerfully supported by the final part of his masterpiece, Gulliver's Travels. In the fourth voyage, Gulliver encounters the Houyhnhnms, a race of intelligent, rational horses, and the Yahoos, who are brutish, disgusting creatures that look exactly like humans. Gulliver is so impressed by the virtue of the horses and so disgusted by the vile nature of the Yahoos that he begins to see all of humanity in the same negative light. When he finally returns to England, he cannot stand the sight or smell of his own family, preferring the company of his horses. This profound rejection of human society suggests that Swift, through his character Gulliver, was expressing a deep-seated disillusionment and contempt for the human race, viewing it as fundamentally corrupt, irrational, and beyond saving.

written.q: Or, What is the message of "Gulliver's Travels-Voyage to Lilliput."
written.a:
The Message of 'Voyage to Lilliput'

The primary message of Gulliver's first voyage to Lilliput is a powerful satire on human pride, pettiness, and political absurdity. By making the inhabitants of Lilliput physically tiny, Swift suggests that their concerns, conflicts, and ambitions are morally and intellectually small. The fierce political rivalry between the High-Heels and Low-Heels, which represents the Whig and Tory parties of England, is shown to be ridiculous. The war with the neighboring island of Blefuscu, which started over the correct way to break an egg, is a brilliant critique of the trivial reasons behind serious and bloody religious and national conflicts. Through Lilliput, Swift sends a clear message that much of human politics, pride, and conflict is foolish, irrational, and insignificant when seen from a different perspective.

written.q: 3. Write short notes with examples (any four): Epigram, Satire, Metaphor, Simulation, Allegory, Paradox
written.a:
Short Notes on Literary Terms

1. Epigram

An epigram is a short, witty, and clever statement that often contains a surprising or paradoxical twist. It is memorable and makes the reader think.

Example: 'I can resist everything except temptation.' - Oscar Wilde.

2. Satire

Satire is a literary technique that uses humor, irony, exaggeration, or ridicule to expose and criticize the foolishness and corruption of an individual or a society.

Example: Jonathan Swift's Gulliver's Travels is a famous satire that criticizes English politics and human nature.

3. Metaphor

A metaphor is a figure of speech that makes a direct comparison between two unlike things without using 'like' or 'as'. It states that one thing is another thing.

Example: 'All the world's a stage, and all the men and women merely players.' - William Shakespeare.

4. Allegory

An allegory is a story in which the characters and events are symbols that stand for abstract ideas or historical events. It has a literal meaning and a deeper, symbolic meaning.

Example: George Orwell's Animal Farm is an allegory for the Russian Revolution.

However, when student politics becomes entangled with national political parties, it often turns negative. Campuses can become battlegrounds for partisan conflicts, leading to violence, disruption of studies, and a toxic academic environment. For student politics to be beneficial, it must remain independent and focused on the genuine welfare of students, rather than serving the interests of external political groups.

written.q: 1. Assert the importance of oral language practice (speaking) in learning English. Describe how you will involve your students in speaking practice.
written.a:
Importance of Oral Practice

Oral language practice, or speaking, is critically important in learning English. It is the most direct way for students to develop fluency and confidence. Speaking helps to activate passive vocabulary and internalize grammatical structures, moving them from theoretical knowledge to practical skill. It improves pronunciation and listening comprehension, as students must both speak and listen to their partners. Regular speaking practice bridges the gap between knowing the language and being able to use it effectively in real-life situations.

Methods for Speaking Practice

To involve students in speaking practice, I would use a variety of interactive methods:

  • Pair Work: Students practice short dialogues or discuss a topic with a partner. This gives every student maximum talking time.
  • Group Discussions: Small groups can debate a topic, solve a problem, or plan an event. This encourages collaboration and communication.
  • Role-Plays: Students act out real-life scenarios, such as ordering food in a restaurant or conducting a job interview.
  • Presentations: Students prepare and deliver short talks on a topic of their choice, which builds public speaking skills.

written.q: Or, What is code switching? Describe the types of code switching. Is code switching the same as code mixing?
written.a:
Code Switching

Code-switching is the practice of alternating between two or more languages or dialects within a single conversation. It is a common and natural behavior among bilingual and multilingual speakers.

Types of Code Switching

  • Intersentential Switching: This occurs when a speaker completes a sentence in one language and then switches to another language for the next sentence.
  • Intra-sentential Switching: This happens within a single sentence, where words or phrases from different languages are mixed.
  • Tag Switching: This is the insertion of a tag or a short phrase from one language into an utterance that is primarily in another language (e.g., 'It's a nice day, isn't it?').

Code Switching vs. Code Mixing

The terms are often used interchangeably, but there can be a subtle difference. Code-mixing is generally considered a type of intra-sentential code-switching, where pieces of different languages are mixed within a sentence or even a word. Some linguists see code-switching as a more conscious choice to switch languages for a specific purpose, while code-mixing can be more subconscious. However, for most general purposes, the terms are considered very similar.

written.q: 2. Describe Gulliver's views about the rearing of children of the Lilliputians.
written.a:
Gulliver's View on Lilliputian Child-Rearing

Gulliver greatly admires the Lilliputian system for raising children. He sees it as highly logical and beneficial to the state. In Lilliput, parents are not considered the primary caregivers. Instead, all children (except those of farmers and laborers) are sent to public nurseries from a very young age. These nurseries are divided by gender and social class. The education focuses on creating virtuous citizens by teaching honor, justice, courage, and patriotism. Gulliver approves of the fact that parents have very limited contact with their children, as he agrees with the Lilliputian belief that this prevents children from being spoiled by parental fondness. He views the entire system as a rational way to ensure all citizens are well-disciplined and useful to society.

written.q: Or, Write in brief on Swift's satire on English politics according to Gulliver's Travel.

Swift's Satire on English Politics

In Gulliver's Travels, Jonathan Swift uses the various lands Gulliver visits to satirize the politics of his time, particularly in England. In Lilliput, the political factions are divided by the height of their heels (High-Heels and Low-Heels), mocking the trivial differences between England's Tory and Whig parties. The method for gaining political officeтАФrope-dancingтАФis a sharp critique of the corrupt and foolish ways politicians sought favor from the monarchy. The absurdly serious war with Blefuscu over which end of an egg to break satirizes the long and bloody conflicts between Protestant England and Catholic France, which Swift felt were based on equally minor disagreements. Through these examples, Swift exposes the pride, corruption, and irrationality he saw in the English political system.

1. Paradox

A paradox is a statement that seems to contradict itself but contains a hidden truth. It challenges the reader to think differently.

Example: 'War is peace. Freedom is slavery. Ignorance is strength.' (From George Orwell's 1984).

2. Simile

A simile is a figure of speech that compares two different things using the words 'like' or 'as' to make a description more vivid.

An allegory is a story where the characters and events are symbols representing abstract ideas or historical events. The entire narrative works on two levels: a literal one and a symbolic one.

Example: The Pilgrim's Progress by John Bunyan is an allegory of a Christian's journey through life.

4. Epigram

An epigram is a brief, witty, and memorable statement that often expresses a clever observation or a surprising thought.

Example: 'The only way to get rid of a temptation is to yield to it.' - Oscar Wilde.

written.q: 1. What is social dialect or sociolect? Describe briefly.
written.a:
Social Dialect or Sociolect

A sociolect is a variety of language (a dialect) spoken by a particular social group. This group can be defined by factors like social class, age, gender, occupation, or ethnicity. Unlike a regional dialect, which is defined by geography, a sociolect is defined by social identity. For example, the language used by lawyers, with its specific legal jargon, can be considered a sociolect. Similarly, the slang and specific vocabulary used by teenagers is another type of sociolect. It's a way for people to show they belong to a certain group.

written.q: Or, Discuss and differentiate between code-switching and code-mixing.
written.a:
Code-Switching vs. Code-Mixing

Code-switching is the practice of moving between two or more languages during a single conversation. It is a common skill among bilingual speakers. For example, speaking one sentence in English and the next in Bengali.

Code-mixing is a specific type of code-switching where a speaker mixes words or phrases from different languages within the same sentence. For example, 'I need to finish this report taaratari (quickly).'

Differentiation:

The main difference is the scope. Code-switching can happen between sentences (intersentential), while code-mixing happens within a single sentence (intra-sentential). Many linguists consider code-mixing to be a sub-category of code-switching, but the key distinction lies in whether the language change occurs at a sentence boundary or within it.

written.a:
Literary Terms Explained

1. Irony

Irony is a figure of speech where there is a significant contrast between what is said and what is actually meant, or between what is expected to happen and what really occurs.

Example: A pilot having a fear of heights.

2. Imagery

Imagery is the use of vivid and descriptive language to appeal to the reader's senses (sight, sound, smell, taste, touch). It helps to create a mental picture.

Example: 'The autumn leaves were a blanket of orange and gold on the crisp, cool ground.'

3. Alliteration

Alliteration is the repetition of the same initial consonant sound in words that are close together in a series.

Example: 'From forth the fatal loins of these two foes.' (Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet)

4. Satire

Satire is a technique used by writers to expose and criticize the foolishness, corruption, or vices of an individual or society by using humor, irony, or exaggeration.

Example: Jonathan Swift's Gulliver's Travels satirizes English society and human nature.

written.q: 3. Narrate the importance of reading. Discuss briefly the steps to be followed for the development of reading skill.
written.a:
The Importance of Reading

Reading is a crucial skill that is fundamental to learning and personal development. It is the primary way we acquire new information, expand our vocabulary, and understand the world around us. Regular reading improves concentration, develops critical and analytical thinking skills, and enhances creativity. It exposes us to different ideas, cultures, and perspectives, fostering empathy and broadening our minds. Furthermore, reading is a proven way to reduce stress and provides a wonderful form of entertainment.

Steps to Develop Reading Skills

  • Read Daily: Make reading a regular habit, even if it's just for 15-20 minutes a day.
  • Choose Your Interests: Select books, articles, or blogs on subjects you find engaging to make the process enjoyable.
  • Expand Your Range: Gradually try different genres and authors to challenge yourself.
  • Focus on Understanding: After reading a section, pause and try to summarize the main points in your own words.
  • Look Up New Words: Keep a dictionary handy to look up unfamiliar words, which helps build your vocabulary.

Monophthongs

A monophthong is a pure vowel sound. During its pronunciation, the position of the tongue and mouth remains the same from beginning to end. It is a single, unchanging sound, unlike a diphthong which glides from one vowel sound to another.

written.q: 1. What is phonetics? Discuss the branches of phonetics.
written.a:
Phonetics

Phonetics is the branch of linguistics that studies the sounds of human speech. It is concerned with how speech sounds are produced, transmitted, and perceived, without regard to their meaning or function within a language.

Branches of Phonetics

Phonetics has three main branches:

  • Articulatory Phonetics: This is the study of how speech sounds are produced by the human vocal organs (the articulators), such as the tongue, lips, and vocal cords.
  • Acoustic Phonetics: This is the study of the physical properties of speech sounds as they travel through the air in the form of sound waves. It deals with properties like frequency and amplitude.
  • Auditory Phonetics: This is the study of how speech sounds are perceived by the ear and processed by the brain. It focuses on how listeners interpret the sound waves they hear.

written.q: Or, Discuss the stages of child language development.
written.a:
Stages of Child Language Development

Children acquire language through a series of predictable stages:

  1. The Pre-linguistic Stage (0-12 months): This stage occurs before actual speech. Babies communicate through crying, cooing (vowel-like sounds), and later, babbling (repeating consonant-vowel combinations like 'bababa').
  2. The Holophrastic (One-Word) Stage (12-18 months): Toddlers begin to use single words to convey entire ideas. For example, 'milk' could mean 'I want more milk.'
  3. The Two-Word Stage (18-24 months): Children start combining two words to create simple sentences, such as 'Mommy go' or 'Big doggie.'
  4. The Telegraphic Stage (2-3 years): Sentences become longer but often lack grammatical function words (like 'the', 'is', 'a'), resembling a telegram. A child might say, 'I want go park.'
  5. Later Development (3+ years): After age three, language skills expand rapidly. Children start using more complex sentence structures, ask many questions, and begin to master the finer rules of grammar.

written.q: 2. Explain the following literary terms: (a) Allegory; (b) Satire; (c) Simile; (d) Metaphore.
written.a:
Literary Terms Explained

(a) Allegory

An allegory is a story in which the characters and events are symbols that represent abstract ideas or historical events. It has a literal meaning and a deeper, symbolic meaning.

Example: George Orwell's Animal Farm is an allegory for the Russian Revolution, with the animals representing key political figures.

(b) Satire

Satire is a literary technique that uses humor, irony, or exaggeration to expose and criticize the foolishness or corruption of an individual or society.

Example: Jonathan Swift's Gulliver's Travels is a satire of English politics and human nature.

(c) Simile

A simile is a figure of speech that makes a comparison between two different things using the words 'like' or 'as'.

Example: 'He runs as fast as the wind.' or 'Her eyes shine like stars.'

(d) Metaphor

A metaphor is a figure of speech that makes a direct comparison between two unlike things without using 'like' or 'as'. It implies that one thing is another.

Example: 'Life is a journey.' In this, life is directly compared to a journey.

written.q: 3. Write a paragraph within 150 words on "ICT in Education".
written.a: Information and Communication Technology (ICT) has revolutionized the field of education, transforming traditional classrooms into dynamic learning environments. ICT provides students and teachers with access to a vast ocean of information through the internet, making learning more engaging and interactive. Tools like smartboards, online tutorials, and educational apps help to explain complex concepts in a simple and visual way. Furthermore, online learning platforms have made education more accessible, allowing students to learn from anywhere at any time. ICT also helps teachers to manage their classes more efficiently and to provide personalized instruction to meet the needs of individual students. By integrating technology into education, we can create a more effective, inclusive, and engaging learning experience for everyone.

written.q: 4. What is psycholinguistics? Explain the process investigated in psycholinguistics.
written.a:
Psycholinguistics

Psycholinguistics is an interdisciplinary field that combines psychology and linguistics. It studies the mental processes that allow humans to acquire, use, understand, and produce language. It is essentially the psychology of language.

Processes Investigated in Psycholinguistics

Psycholinguistics investigates three main processes:

  1. Language Comprehension: This is the process of how we understand spoken and written language. It involves hearing sounds, recognizing words, and interpreting the grammar and meaning of sentences.
  2. Language Production: This is the process of how we create language. It involves having a thought, finding the right words to express it, and then arranging those words into grammatical sentences before speaking or writing them.
  3. Language Acquisition: This is the process of how people, especially children, learn a language. It investigates how we develop the ability to perceive, understand, and use language from infancy onwards.

written.q: 5. What is listening? How can you organize a listening activity in the class?
written.a:
What is Listening?

Listening is an active process of receiving, interpreting, and responding to spoken messages. It is more than just hearing; it involves paying close attention to understand the meaning, information, and emotions being communicated by a speaker.

Organizing a Listening Activity

A well-structured listening activity can be organized in three main stages:

  1. Pre-listening: This stage prepares students for the listening task. The teacher can introduce the topic, pre-teach essential vocabulary, and ask students to predict what they might hear. This activates their background knowledge and creates interest.
  2. While-listening: During this stage, students listen to the audio or the speaker for a specific purpose. They might be asked to listen for the main idea (gist), for specific details, or to fill in a worksheet. The task should be clear and achievable.
  3. Post-listening: After listening, this stage involves follow-up activities to check comprehension and extend learning. Students can discuss their answers in pairs, summarize the content, or participate in a role-play or debate related to the topic.

written.q: 1. What is Sociolinguistics? Explain applied linguistics.
written.a:
Sociolinguistics

Sociolinguistics is the study of the connection between language and society. It examines how social factors like social class, age, gender, and ethnicity influence the way people use language. It helps us understand why different social groups speak differently and how language use changes in various social situations.

Applied Linguistics

Applied Linguistics is a field that uses linguistic theories to solve real-world problems related to language. Its most common application is in language teaching, but it also covers areas like translation, language planning for governments, and speech therapy. It's about the practical use of language knowledge.

written.q: Or, What is meant by code-switching in language use? How can a speaker benefit from code-switching?
written.a:
Code-Switching

Code-switching is the practice of alternating between two or more languages or dialects during a conversation. It is a natural skill used by bilingual or multilingual people.

Benefits of Code-Switching

A speaker can benefit from code-switching in several ways:

  • To Express Identity: It can show that a speaker belongs to a particular social or cultural group.
  • To Clarify Meaning: A speaker might switch to another language to explain a concept that is more easily expressed in that language.
  • To Build Rapport: Switching to a shared language can create a friendly and informal atmosphere between speakers.
  • To Convey Emotion: Sometimes, an emotion or a specific feeling is better expressed with a word or phrase from another language.

written.q: 2. "Internet should be made available to each and every student." Do you agree? Compose an argumentative writing within 150 words mentioning reasons for and against the statement.
written.a: Making the internet available to every student is a goal with strong arguments on both sides. On one hand, providing universal internet access would be a massive step towards educational equality. It gives all students access to a vast world of information, online courses, and collaborative tools, regardless of their location or background. This prepares them for a digital future. However, there are significant challenges. The primary concern is the 'digital divide'; many families cannot afford the necessary devices or a stable connection. Furthermore, unrestricted internet access can lead to major distractions like social media and gaming, and exposes students to potentially harmful content. While the benefits are clear, providing internet to all students must be done carefully, with proper funding, support, and guidelines to ensure it is used as a tool for learning, not just entertainment.

written.q: 3. Describe the child rearing customs and laws of the Lilliputians as depicted in Gulliver's Travels.
written.a:
Child-Rearing in Lilliput

In Gulliver's Travels, the Lilliputians have a unique and highly organized system for raising children, which Gulliver admires. They believe that parents are not fit to raise their own children, so the state takes full responsibility. Children are sent to public nurseries from a young age, which are segregated by gender and social class. The education they receive is focused on making them virtuous and useful citizens, emphasizing honor, justice, and patriotism. Parents are allowed to see their children only twice a year for a very short time. This is to ensure the children are not spoiled by parental affection. The entire system is designed to produce disciplined individuals who will serve the commonwealth effectively.

written.q: 4. What are your views about Gulliver, the main character of Gulliver's Travels?
written.a:
Views on Lemuel Gulliver

Lemuel Gulliver is a complex character who serves as the lens for Swift's satire rather than being a traditional hero. Initially, he appears as an ordinary, practical, and somewhat naive English surgeon. He is a keen observer and adapts remarkably well to the bizarre situations he finds himself in. However, his character undergoes a profound transformation throughout his voyages. His experiences, particularly with the rational Houyhnhnms and the beastly Yahoos, fill him with a deep disgust for humanity. By the end, he becomes a misanthrope, unable to stand the presence of other humans, including his own family. He is a tragic figure whose journey reveals the follies and corruption of mankind.

written.q: 5. Why is following the stages in teaching reading skill important for an English teacher?
written.a:
Importance of Stages in Teaching Reading

Following the three stages of teaching reading (pre-reading, while-reading, and post-reading) is crucial for an English teacher because it provides a logical and effective framework for learning. The pre-reading stage prepares students by activating their background knowledge, introducing key vocabulary, and setting a purpose for reading, which builds motivation. The while-reading stage guides students to read actively and strategically, helping them focus on understanding the main ideas or specific details without feeling overwhelmed. Finally, the post-reading stage allows students to check their comprehension, reflect on the text's meaning, and connect what they have read to other skills like speaking or writing. This structured approach makes reading less intimidating and ensures a deeper, more meaningful understanding of the text.

written.q: 1. What is phonetics? Discuss the different branches of phonetics.
written.a:
Phonetics

Phonetics is the scientific study of speech sounds. It is concerned with how sounds are produced by the vocal organs, their physical properties, and how they are perceived by the listener, independent of their meaning in a language.

Branches of Phonetics

The main branches of phonetics are:

  • Articulatory Phonetics: Studies how speech sounds are made (articulated) using the vocal organs like the tongue, lips, and teeth.
  • Acoustic Phonetics: Studies the physical properties of speech sounds as they travel through the air in the form of sound waves.
  • Auditory Phonetics: Studies how speech sounds are perceived by the ear and processed by the brain.

written.q: Or, Explain and exemplify code-switching as a phenomenon of code-mixing.
written.a:
Code-Switching and Code-Mixing

Code-switching is the broader term for alternating between two or more languages in a conversation. Code-mixing is a specific type of code-switching that happens within a single sentence or clause. Therefore, code-mixing is a phenomenon or an example of code-switching.

For example, when a speaker says, 'The weather is nice today. Cholo baire jai (Let's go outside),' this is inter-sentential code-switching (switching between sentences).

However, when a speaker says, 'Amar project-ta finish korte hobe (I have to finish my project),' this is code-mixing, as the English word 'finish' is mixed into a Bengali sentence structure. This act of mixing is a clear instance of the broader phenomenon of code-switching.

written.q: 2. Write a paragraph on: Importance of reading good books.

Importance of Reading Good Books

Reading good books is one of the most beneficial habits a person can cultivate. It is a gateway to endless knowledge, allowing us to explore different cultures, historical periods, and scientific ideas from the comfort of our homes. written.q: 3. Describe the principles of developing reading activities.
written.a:
Principles of Developing Reading Activities

Effective reading activities are typically developed based on a three-stage framework:

  • Principle 1: Pre-Reading Stage. The goal here is to prepare the learner. Activities should activate students' prior knowledge about the topic, introduce key vocabulary they will encounter, and set a clear purpose for reading. This motivates students and makes the text less intimidating.
  • Principle 2: While-Reading Stage. The focus here is on comprehension. Activities should guide the students through the text, helping them to understand the main ideas (gist) or find specific information. The tasks should be engaging and help students interact with the text, not just passively read it.
  • Principle 3: Post-Reading Stage. This stage is for consolidation and extension. Activities should allow students to check their understanding, reflect on what they have read, and connect the text's content to their own experiences or other skills like speaking and writing.

written.q: 4. Write a critical note on Swift's satire on English politics according to 'A Voyage to Lilliput' of Gulliver's Travels.
written.a:
A Critical Note on Swift's Satire in 'A Voyage to Lilliput'

In 'A Voyage to Lilliput,' Jonathan Swift masterfully uses the miniature world of Lilliput to launch a sharp and critical satire on the absurdity of English politics. The political factions, the Tramecksan (High-Heels) and Slamecksan (Low-Heels), are a direct mockery of the trivial differences between England's Tory and Whig parties. Swift critiques the corrupt system of political appointments through the ridiculous ritual of rope-dancing, where politicians who leap the highest without falling gain high office, suggesting that political skill in England is mere flattery and dangerous games. Most powerfully, the war between Lilliput and Blefuscu over which end of an egg to break (the Big-Endians vs. the Little-Endians) is a brilliant satire of the long, bloody, and, in Swift's view, pointless religious conflicts between Protestant England and Catholic France. Through these examples, Swift portrays English politics as petty, irrational, and driven by pride rather than reason.

written.q: 5. Elaborate on the product approach of writing.
written.a:
The Product Approach of Writing

The product approach is a traditional method of teaching writing that focuses entirely on the final piece of text produced by the student. The main belief of this approach is that the goal of a writing lesson is to create a correct and well-structured 'product'.

In this approach, the teacher typically provides a model text for students to imitate. The emphasis is on accuracy in grammar, spelling, punctuation, and vocabulary. The process that the student goes throughтАФplanning, drafting, revisingтАФis not given much importance. The teacher's role is primarily that of an evaluator, who marks the final text for errors. While this approach can be useful for helping students master specific grammatical forms, it is often criticized for being rigid and for not encouraging creativity or developing the student's voice as a writer.

organizationManagement.content:
Organization and Management of Educational Institutions

Course Code: 220349

Course Description

This provides an understanding of the concept of organization, educational management, its functions and principles and educational institutions as social organizations. This course also deals with the organization and management of physical and social aspects of schools and colleges, organization and management of curriculum, evaluation and examinations, innovations, co-curricular activities, library and school funds. The course is designed to explore the roles and responsibilities of the heads of the institutions, leadership qualities, human relations, and communications, efficiency, values and ethics in institutional management and administration.

Course Objectives:

To assist the students so that they

  • Understand the concept, goals and functions of educational institutional management, structures and functions at different levels;
  • Acquaint themselves with the concept and practices of educational management, structures and functions at different levels and institutional management,
  • Understand the organization and management aspects of physical facilities of schools and colleges,
  • Gain experience necessary for developing skills on institutional planning, curriculum management, time table construction, academic supervision, organization and management of evaluation and examination;
  • Develop skills in organizing and managing library services, school health services and co-curricular activities.
  • Understand the concept and acquire skills of an effective leader, communicator and human relations.
  • Realize that acquisition and application of proper values and ethics in management is vital for organizations and education thus to the nation.

Course Contents

Unit One: Organization as Social System

  • Meaning, definitions, types & functions of organization,
  • Principles of organizational climate, organization as social system
  • Educational institutions (School & Colleges) as social organizations
  • Structure, objectives and programmes of educational institutions

Unit Two: Management Structure of Educational Institutions (Schools & Colleges)

  • Meaning of administration and management, school and college administration
  • Process, functions and general/basic principles, styles of management
  • Types of administrative and management structure of schools and colleges
  • Functions and responsibilities of the Ministries of Education and line Directorates in relation to schools and colleges
  • School management committee and governing body

Unit Three: Role of Heads as Leaders

  • Roles and Responsibilities of the head master/principal
  • Role of Head as Leaders
  • Meaning and concepts and styles of leadership
  • Attributes of a successful leader
  • Human relations in schools and college - staff, pupil, community, parent, government officers

Unit Four: Management of Curricular Activities

  • Time-table, academic supervision, staff development program
  • Examination and evaluation
  • Library services
  • Co-curricular Activities

Unit Five: Management of School Funds & Other Resources

  • Budget, maintenance of account and audit
  • Institutional plant facilities (site, building, furniture, equipments, library, laboratory, workshop, play-ground, recreational facilities)
  • School improvement programs: Institutional planning

Unit Six: Practicum

  • Development of an institutional plan
  • Construction of time-table
  • Case-Study, Role-playing

Gender Education

Course Code: 220351

Course Description

Now-a-days Gender is a burning issue in education sector. This course is designed to assist students and respective teachers to concern about gender and build up insights in to learners behavior on it. It covers concepts, principles and aims of Gender and as well as life skills in education, its influence on family and the society. It also covers role of students, teachers, parents and relevant stakeholders awareness to create a gender biasness society.

Course Objectives

  • To help learners to understand and realize the need of Gender Education in their real life and build up their career in future
  • To understand them to familiar with some key terms of Gender Education , and practice it positively in life
  • To help them to create a gender friendly environment and aware them about their own roles
  • To facilitate them to identify life skills, gender related laws and acts, and practice it in life
  • To assist them how to take help from NGOs and development partners, and able to build up their career.

Course Contents

Unit 1: Gender-Concept, Significance, Application

  • Concept, origin and development of gender; gender and sex comparison
  • Aims and objectives of Gender Education
  • Concept of- Gender equity, gender equality, gender mainstreaming, gender analysis, gender sensitiveness, gender role and gender division of labor
  • Identify the wrong concept of gender- causes, impact and remedies
  • Mass media and women
  • Approaches to women- valuation and devaluation of women

Unit 2: Gender disparities, Consciousness and Women empowerment

  • Concept of gender disparities, causes and remedies; nature and statistics of torture to women
  • Women-men situation in Bangladesh and the world
  • Need of gender consciousness in socio-economic development, create gender friendly environment
  • Concept of women empowerment; familial, social, political, administrative and economical , decision making empowerment
  • Security of women, women and children pacher

Unit 3: Secondary Education- Learners and gender

  • Role of gender education in learners development
  • Influences of teacher to generate positive approaches and behavior to female learners- in-house, school and on the way to school and home
  • Gender consciousness areas of learners in familial social life
  • Role of family and society on learners skill development; equal distribution of fundamental rights of daughter and son for all round development; reforms of traditional approaches to work distribution of male and female
  • School management and gender- ensure women representation in SMC, PTA, Participating attempts and encouragement
  • Gender equality in secondary education- role of government and other institutions, Impact and results of female stipend; Impact of PROMOTE; Increase of female teachers in secondary level
  • Gender sensitiveness in classroom activities- seating arrangement, equal participation into class, enhance female learners participation in classroom activities

Unit 4: Professionalism in teaching and Gender

  • Role of teacher to established social justice- concept of social justice, Globalization and social justice, teacher and social justice
  • Gender sensitiveness in teaching- observation of teaching of teacher, demonstration teaching competencies and classroom management
  • Gender consciousness strategies- number of students, socio-economic conditions, merits, school environment, learners behavior in house and in school
  • Challenges to implementation gender education in school- rural and urban learners, forward and backward learners, meritorious and non-meritorious learners, majority and minority, guardians and school authority, social custom and religion, big class vs small class of learners, and political impact

Unit 5: Gender- National and International perspectives

  • Gender in- Human rights, Rights of male, female and children, development and poverty, employment, violence, women pacher, sexuality, HIV/AIDS, Child abuse, domestic violence
  • Gender in national policies, and plans- the constitution of Bangladesh, Women in Development(WID), Gender and Development(GAD), Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper(PRSP), National Policy for Women Affairs(NPWA)-2008, National Policy for Women Development
  • Gender sensitive laws in Bangladesh
  • Role of NGOs and Development Partners(DP) in gender development

Unit 6: Life skills and Gender

  • Concept life skills, 10 life skills by WHO
  • Aims and objectives of life skills education
  • Introducing life skills- Role play and discussion
  • Sub skills and micro skills of life skills, ways of achieving life skills

English Paper- II

Course Code: 220355

Course Content

Unit 1. Introduction to linguistics 1

  • Phonetics and phonology
  • Semantics

Introduction to linguistics II

  • Sociolinguistics
  • Psycholinguistics

Unit 2. Mechanics of writing

  • Paragraph writing by compare and contrast, cause and effect, argumentative writing, persuasive writing,
  • Writing notes, emails, formal and informal writing such as CV, application, notice, rejoinder, responding to formal /informal letters, analyzing and interpreting graphs and charts
  • Report writing (official and newspaper), composition
  • Cohesion, coherence
  • Punctuation
  • Bibliography and referencing following APA style

Unit 3. Appreciation of literature

  • Genre, style, mood and tone, rhetoric and prosody, scansion,
  • Literary terms: simile, metaphor, irony, imagery, allegory, pun, illusion, transferred epithet, metonymy, synecdoche, paradox, alliteration, epigram, conceit, satire
  • Discourse analysis

Unit 4. Reading

  • Jonathon Swift : GulliverтАЩs Travels-Voyage to Lilliput

Unit 5. Writing

  • Critical Appreciation: short/broad questions, explanations

Unit 6. Teaching and learning of language skills

  • Teaching and learning of Listening skills: stages of a listening lesson, techniques of effective listening
  • Teaching and learning of Speaking skills: involving students in speaking through pairwork, groupwork, simulation, role play, play, guided and free speaking
  • Teaching and learning of Reading skills: stages of a reading lesson, advantages and disadvantages of loud reading and silent reading, scanning, skimming, inferencing, guessing from the context, different techniques of effective reading.
  • Teaching and learning of writing skills: stages of a writing lesson; guided, semi-guided and free writing; product approach and process approach
  • Integrating skills in a lesson (PPP model)
